Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Affordable point-of-use water disinfection through mass-produced nano-silver embedded paper filters
Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is the reduction of waterborne disease from drinking water in low-income populations. 2.1 billion people drink fecally-contaminated water, 50% of hospitalization in developing countries are due to waterborne diseases, and contaminated drinking water causes >500,000 diarrheal deaths each year. Low-income populations not only pay for water, but pay anywhere from 30% to 10 times more in absolute terms than the wealthy. This proposed technical innovation will provide: a consumer packaged goods water filter, i.e. a product priced as a consumable and sold through food/beverage retail grocery stores. This is a different business model than water filters which are sold as durable good appliances through specialty stores. If successful a new consumer water filter category reaching a fraction of 2.1 B people has potential to represent a $1B+ category. This proposed project would bring the innovation closer to commercialization by creating a more robust performing antimicrobial filter paper through challenge water stress testing.


This SBIR Phase I project proposes to develop a nano-silver antimicrobial filter paper through mass-production methods, e.g. paper machines, that is formulated to be biocidal in a wide variety of water sources. Technical hurdles include the reliability of technology scaling, developing frameworks for quality and stress testing, broader antimicrobial efficacy, and longer use life. The project goals include engineering a paper formulation with increased silver uptake, more uniform nanoparticle synthesis, synergistic antimicrobial chemicals, and reliable filter paper pore size and flow rate. The project plan to address these technical challenges include rigorous stress testing with specific challenge chemicals and high microbial loads, development of new formulations based on adding synergistic antimicrobial chemicals, absorbent chemicals to increase silver uptake, and process variations in the operation of the paper machine (speed, temperature, pressing, etc). These experiments will require new formulations to be evaluated following the same quality and stress tests with each iteration at the bench scale and pilot scale.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

Key outcomes of the NSF SBIR Phase I research and development activity are product stress-testing and pilot scale production of Folia's patent-pending nano-silver filter paper for a consumer goods water filter for antimicrobial point-of-use water purification. 

1. Determine potential 'real world water' failure points of Folia Filters through bacterial viability in water chemical stress test conditions.

2. Create new filter paper formulations to address failure points

3. Validate these filter paper improvements through stress tests

4. Scale-up the filter paper improvements from small pilot to medium pilot machines

Additional accomplishments include:

  • Demonstration of iron removal per customer request from Bangladesh sales trials meeting the NSF International standard
  • Increased flow rates by 2.4x
  • Demonstration of pilot-scale manufacturing consistency and quality control
  •   Development of a HIgh-Throughput semi-Automated Parallel testing system (HI-TAP)
  • Filed 2 provisional patents based on inventions from this research
Broader/Commercial  Impacts:

 

Folia Water is a B2B materials company with a patented process to use paper machines to make nanomaterials at the large scale and penny costs of paper mills, commercializing a mass-market antimicrobial water purifier for export to emerging markets starting with S/SE Asia. Folia Water's flagship product is the Folia Filter, a simple, antimicrobial paper water filter packaged like a coffee filter that retails at 20 cents for 20 liters of safe-germ free water. Folia Filters are the world's first water filters that cost pennies and not dollars. Folia Filters create a new ~$10B sub-category of consumer packaged goods (CPG) water purifier with the performance and price per liter of a $20-200 durable good appliance water purifier, with the price point, distribution, and sales channels of mass-market grocery store staples like soap, shampoo, and SIM cards. They are a 75-95% savings compared to bottled water, which is a $58B market in emerging markets alone. This lets us sell to working class families in emerging markets earning $2-10 a day, and collectively spending $5T on grocery staples. No other water purification product exists that can achieve the same price point as other grocery store items while meeting consumer requirements, leading to a major market failure with 1.4B emerging market working class consumers currently drinking microbially contaminated drinking water. We aim to massively reduce the number of families drinking dirty water, significantly decreasing the 500,000 deaths and 50% of emerging market hospitalizations caused by drinking dirty water.

As a B2B materials technology company, we aim to commercialize by licensing or selling our IP or product lines to large corporates with country-, regional-, or global-scale distribution and sales reach, here through CPG grocery retail channels. Mass market grocery channels are the low margin/high volume world of CPG firms like Unilever and P&G selling billions of units rather than the low volume/high margin world of all other water filters, which are sold either as appliances or as capital equipment. Unilever has given us a $400k grant for a sales pilot in Bangladesh to demonstrate consumer demand and product market fit based on our previous proof of concept manufacturing at industrial scale and product performance under reasonable conditions. However, enterprise-scale CPG and water corporates have been clear that prior to commercializing our product beyond pilot phase, Folia must demonstrate that we can reliability manufacture our product in a careful and rigorous manner, with clear and bracketed risk-mitigating claims around antimicrobial performance under various real world conditions. Furthermore, we must also demonstrate consumer product-market fit, i.e. that we that we have the right product performance to achieve consumer requirements. This required the implementation of the technical improvements that were successfully accomplished in this project as well as those contained in the subsequent Phase II project.
